Marvin Toll wrote:
> Neil,
>
> Your suggestion has a spark of creativity; although I'm unclear if it 
> contemplated companies that are "inside-the-container" test shops.  
> Perhaps you were thinking of running JUnit from a 1.5 JVM redirecting 
> to a 1.4 application server?  hhmmm ...
>   
All the more reason to develop tests that don't need to run in a container.
>  
> The development and promotion environment at a large company is very 
> (or "very very") prescriptive.  Creativity is exercised in solving 
> business problems - not in configuring the environment.  (Or, even in 
> using the latest and greatest technology.)
>
>   
It seems to me that the latest and greatest technology being 
experimented with here is Junit 4, not Java 5. To use Java 5 for running 
Junit it would not need to be "installed" by sysadmins anymore than you 
need a sysadmin to install junit 4. You just need a JRE somewhere. It 
could even be in source control (assuming that's allowed by the license).

- Neil
